facts.text: 1st Respondent's duty included accepting goods from public and issuing Way Bills.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st Respondent was the Agent of Shree Narayana Transport Company of one of its Branches namely at Baliapattom and in that capacity it was one of his duties to accept goods from the Public for transporting them by lorry service of the Company

facts.text: 1st Respondent issued nine Way Bills on different dates in favour of the 2nd Respondent as if goods were received but no such goods were accepted or dispatched.

issues.text: Whether under Section 494 CrPC the Public Prosecutor must make up his mind to withdraw from the prosecution without any reference to the State Government and exercise independent judgment, or can be directed/influenced by the Government?

anchor.surface_text: It is contended before us that under Sec. 494 Criminal Procedure Code it is the Public Prosecutor and the Public Prosecutor alone who should make up his mind to withdraw from the prosecution without any reference to the State Government, that it was the State Government which directed the Public Prosecutor to seek permission as such the Public Prosecutor has not adverted his mind nor did he exercise his independent judgment in deciding whether the case is one in which permission of the Court to withdraw from the prosecution ought to have been asked for.

issues.text: Whether permission to withdraw the prosecution under Section 494 CrPC ought to have been granted on the grounds disclosed in the Public Prosecutor's memo (civil nature, decision in civil suit, delay since 1963, distant witnesses, heavy expenses)?

anchor.surface_text: In any case it is submitted on the grounds disclosed in the Memo filed by the Public Prosecutor that no permission ought to have been given as even prior to the filing of the said Memo. the High Court had said that there was a prima facie case for the trial to go on and therefore the present order directing the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution is manifestly contrary to the views earlier expressed by it.

issues.text: Whether the permission to withdraw from the prosecution under Section 494 CrPC was sought and granted in the interest of administration of justice?

anchor.surface_text: What then are the circumstances in which the permission has been sought in this case and the considerations that weighed with the Courts in granting that permission. The Public Prosecutor as we have seen thought that the matter was of a civil nature, that the subject matter of the case before the Magistrate had been decided in a Civil suit,

arguments.claim: Delay, expense, practice not established do not justify withdrawal; trial must proceed

anchor.surface_text: We think that these grounds are flimsy and do not justify the granting of permission to withdraw from the prosecution. In the first place there is nothing to indicate what that practice was, how it was resorted to and what elements were definition to constitute the offences for which the Respondents were entitled to be charged and in the second place nothing had happened since the committal order

holdings.text: Though the Section is in general terms and does not circumscribe the powers of the Public Prosecutor to seek permission to withdraw from the prosecution the essential consideration which is implicit in the grant of the power is that it should be in the interest of administration of justice which may be either that it will not be able to produce sufficient evidence to sustain the charge or that subsequent information before prosecuting agency would falsify the prosecution evidence or any other similar circumstances which it is difficult to predicate as they are dependent entirely on the facts and circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Section is in general terms and does not circumscribe the powers of the Public Prosecutor to seek permission to withdraw from the prosecution the essential consideration which is implicit in the grant of the power is that it should be in the interest of administration of justice which may be either that it will not be able to produce sufficient evidence to sustain the charge or that subsequent information before prosecuting agency would falsify the prosecution evidence or any other similar circumstances which it is difficult to predicate as they are dependent entirely on the facts and circumstances of each case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive reading of wide discretionary power under Sec. 494 CrPC requires it to advance administration of justice; court duty to prevent extraneous or improper executive influence, illustrated by precedents quashing permissions on policy grounds.

holdings.text: It appears to us that the wide and general powers which are conferred under Sec. 494 on the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution though they are subject to the permission of the Court have to be exercised by him in relation to the facts and circumstances of that case in furtherance of, rather than as a hindrance to the object of the law and justified on the material in the case which substantiate the grounds alleged.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the wide and general powers which are conferred under Sec. 494 on the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution though they are subject to the permission of the Court have to be exercised by him in relation to the facts and circumstances of that case in furtherance of, rather than as a hindrance to the object of the law and justified on the material in the case which substantiate the grounds alleged, not necessarily from those gathered by the judicial method but on other materials which may not be strictly on legal or admissible evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public Prosecutor must independently apply mind to case materials even if directed by government; court examines if function properly exercised without illegitimate interference.

holdings.text: It is clear that prima facie none of these grounds or even the cumulative effect of all these grounds would justify the withdrawal from the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evaluates specific grounds (civil nature, prior civil suit decision, delay, distant witnesses, expense) as inadequate for withdrawal under Sec. 494 as they do not serve administration of justice.

holdings.text: We think that these grounds are flimsy and do not justify the granting of permission to withdraw from the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Section is in general terms and does not circumscribe the powers of the Public Prosecutor to seek permission to withdraw from the prosecution the essential consideration which is implicit in the grant of the power is that it should be in the interest of administration of justice which may be either that it will not be able to produce sufficient evidence to sustain the charge or that subsequent information before prosecuting agency would falsify the prosecution evidence or any other similar circumstances which it is difficult to predicate as they are dependent entirely on the facts and circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the wide and general powers which are conferred under Sec. 494 on the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution though they are subject to the permission of the Court have to be exercised by him in relation to the facts and circumstances of that case in furtherance of, rather than as a hindrance to the object of the law and justified on the material in the case which substantiate the grounds alleged, not necessarily from those gathered by the judicial method but on other materials which may not be strictly on legal or admissible evidence.
